title: thought for the week october 1 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowInsects are tiny creatures, but they make a massive contribution in keeping our world in balance.They are responsible for the pollination of about  per cent of trees and bushes on the entire planet. Yet we often treat them in a dismissive way.Let#s think about some insects.Take the bluebottle. How often has it outwitted us with its amazing flight paths, ducking and ing to avoid our threatening gestures.While we have developed some of the most sophisticated flying machines the world has known, none can match the bluebottle in its agility.We have mentioned pollination. What insect is more important than the bee as it goes about its business from flower to flower ensuring that the plants will produce seed for another year and giving us honey as a product of its labours.How beautul too are its colours and the structure of its body – a remarkable little insect.Then there is the humble moth and its gravity-defying antics walking across ceilings. It has a very fragile body but in its short le can nevertheless act out its own acrobatic skill in an amazing performance.Or we may think of the spider and the beauty of its web, perhaps seen on a frosty winter morning. A true work of art woven with such delicacy.In the bible we read this: #Go watch the ants, you lazy person. Watch what they do and be wise. Ants have no commander, no leader or ruler, but they store up food in the summer and gather their supplies at harvest.# From this we can learn four things helpful to living: be diligent and hard-working have an #I can do it# attitude plan ahead remember teamwork is important.

title: scout-adkin-qualifies-world-championships-thailand
story: PEEBLES hill-running siblings Scout and Jacob Adkin were both in action at the British Championships at Sedbergh in the Lake District last weekend.Scout Adkin took the womenrsquos senior title finishing more than a minute ahead of Katherine Maltby who claimed second place and a signicant margin ahead Naomi Leng in third position.The race was also the trial for the World Mountain Running Championships in Thailand next February and Scoutrsquos victory guarantees her selection for that tournament.Jacob, however, took fourth place despite an injury which later ended with a hospital visit and an avulsion fracture diagnosis.He injured his ankle on the first descent but continued and was visibly in pain, hobbling over the finish line.This contributed to Scotlandrsquos senior men beating England by a single point.ldquoFortunately it is not a lsquoproperrsquo broken leg, he told the Scottish Athletics website.ldquoI was in a bit of pain but didnrsquot want to let the team down and it was brilliant for Scotland to get two sets of team golds.ldquoThe diagnosis was that it was a clean little fracture at the end of the bone and Irsquom not in plaster of anything like that. The doctors think it best to allow me to move it as much as I can.ldquoIrsquom hoping to be able to do some cross training soon.

title: another-triathlon-win-peebles-athlete-wales
story: A PEEBLES athlete has won The Roc Wales triathlon ndash breaking the previous course record by completing it in four hours and  minutes.Iain Veitch took part in the brutal race which showcases some of the most breathtaking and rugged scenery the UK has to offer.The field this year was particularly strong with the top four athletes all beating the previous course record.A m sea swim at the Welsh coastal town of Abersoch was followed by a demanding km ride through Snowden national park.It was then on to running the famously tough Watkins path to the summit of Snowden itself.After coming back down, athletes then rode the km back to Abersoch where the race concluded with a km run on the beach.The -year-old told us: ldquoThe course was brilliant. A beach start sea swim in cold but calm waters off the gorgeous beach of Abersoch."An honest rolling bike course and a run up the infamous Watkins Path of Wales highest mountain. It really has that wow factor.ldquoDespite the good swimming conditions I swam poorly and quickly fell to the back of the elite pack and stayed there until coming out the water."The support at the event was brilliant. The noise from supporters giving a real boost regardless of position.ldquoThe bike conditions were almost perfect. No strong winds, dry and a reasonably hilly undulating course from the coast to the main feature of the event ndash Snowden. Even though the racing was tough the scenery en route was stunning."It was also quite intimidating as you could clearly see at all times what lay ahead on the run.ldquoThe run up the mountain was brutal. The Watkins path is often described as the toughest but most scenic path up the mountain and lived up to this."The terrain is relentlessly steep reducing everyone to a scramble near the top."The views though made up for the suffering. Jaw dropping.ldquoBy the time I was back down the mountain I had taken the lead."Despite being halted at a level train crossing and having a very anxious wait for the train to pass and the barrier to raise I was able to hold onto that to the end of the second bike leg and really enjoy the last k run on the beach."

story: A SONGS of Praise to help raise funds for the Tearfund charity will take place at the Trinity Church in Galashiels on Sunday  October at .pmThe event aims to raise much-needed funds for the people in war torn AfghanistanThose attending have chosen a selection of old and new hymns to be sung at the event.These include O For a Thousand Tongues, Will You Come and Follow Me, Father Hear the Prayer We Offer, The King of Love, Teach Me To Dance, In Christ Alone, Great in Thy Faithfulness, I Want to Walk with Jesus, The Old Rugged Cross, Out of My Bondage, Love Divine, Just As I Am, Beauty for Brokenness, Will your Anchor Hold, Bless My Lord Oh My Soul, There is a Redeemer, Blessed Assurance and Ye gates Lt Up Your Head.In addition, the reverend Jim Wallace will play one of his songs and there will possibly be a solo from acclaimed soprano Mhairi Lawson.Covid restrictions will determine the number of people permitted in the building on the night, but it is anticipated that everyone attending will be accommodated.The seating will be on a lsquofirst come, first servedrsquo basis and should the numbers be larger than the maximum permitted the event will be repeated at a later date.All money raised will go to the Tearfund Afghanistan crisis appeal. title: headstone-safety-checks-borders-council-aims-avoid-distress
story: A TWEEDDALE representative says the council will try to contact ldquoall the relatives involved as the next phase of headstone safety checks draw closer.As reported by this newspaper, Scottish Borders Councilwill be carrying out the tests in graveyards across the region next year.During the  inspection,  headstones were toppled in St Andrews Cemetery sparking outrage in the community.It was revealed at a meeting of Peebles Community Council last month that SBC officers will be trying to contact relatives, as the local authority says it did during the previous phase of testing.:Borders motorist who admitted careless driving is finedThis has been disputed by local man David Brunton, who, in a freedom of information request, claims he received a response from SBC stating that ldquoit did not contact lair holders.At this monthrsquos meeting, community councillor Peter Maudsley said: ldquoWe are all aware of the distress that this caused back in , and I donrsquot think anyone would deny at this time that itrsquos crucial to get the job done correctly.Independent Tweeddale East councillor Robin Tatler has confirmed that relatives will be able to get their own monumental stonemason to carry out work on headstones ahead of testing.He added: ldquoI want to absolutely make sure that this process is dealt with as well as it possibly can for the relatives whorsquove got gravestones in the cemetery. So what we will be doing is establishing the date for the scheduled testing and, at the earliest opportunity, arrange a meeting with the relatives to go through the process.An outside contractor carried out the previous tests, with the safety scheme being dubbed ldquovandalism by a member of Peebles Community Council.:Premier Inn walks away from Business Gateway plans in TweedbankHowever, the next phase will be carried out by SBC employees.ldquoWhat the relatives will be able to do well in advance of the  days, which was the previous advance warning, is to meet with the people that do the testing and officers to answer queries and worries that they have about this, said Mr Tatler.He said he wanted to ensure it would cause ldquoas little distress as possible this time around.Mr Tatler told that meeting that best practice would be used by the council, ldquoas we did last time.But Mr Maudsley claimed that during the last phase, Scottish Government guidelines for burial ground memorial safety did not appear to be followed.ldquoYou might recollect that I put a report together back in , said Mr Maudsley. ldquoA member of the public that contacted me recently was concerned that the Peeblesshire News carried an article stating that the officers were going to be doing as they did previously in trying to contact relatives. But back in , our investigations didnrsquot seem to demonstrate that much had actually been attempted in contacting the relatives at the time.:Here are the new opening hours for Borders recycling centresMr Tatler said he was not in a position to comment on what happened in , adding: ldquoI came in at the end of the process, and we responded to peoplesrsquo concerns about that. I believe they did make efforts, but it was the older part of the graveyard they were dealing with, so perhaps it was more challenging to find relatives that were still alive effectively. This time around, I know they will be attempting to contact all the relatives involved.Following the meeting, this paper contacted SBC for a statement.A spokesperson said: ldquoAs a local authority we are ultimately responsible for the management and upkeep of burial grounds in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThis responsibility includes ensuring the safety of those visiting and working in their burial grounds.ldquoPrior to any testing, the council erects notices at any entrances into a cemetery and contacts relevant local members and community councils in advance of these works taking place.ldquoAs with all of the work we carry out in graveyards, we will ensure the work is undertaken with due respect and only by trained staff.ldquoI can confirm that we have received a complaint in relation to works being undertaken in cemeteries within a conservation area protected by a statutory listing. An investigation into this complaint is currently taking place.

title: borders-book-festival-2021-big-names-visiting-borders-november
story: HILARY MANTEL, Alexander McCall Smith, Ian Rankin and former Prime Minister Gordon Brown are all set to visit the region in November for this yearrsquos Borders Book Festival.Last year the event was held virtually.But this year it will be held at Abbotsford, the home of Sir Walter Scott from November -.The line-up for this year has now been revealed, with festival director Alistair Moffat saying he is ldquodelighted to welcome book lovers back to the festival.Mr Moffat said: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted to be welcoming the book-loving public back to the Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival this year, even more so in light of everything that the last  months has thrown at us.This year the Borders Book Festival will cover more than  events, including a celebration of the th Walter Scott Prize for Historical Fiction which was awarded to Hilary Mantel in June for her book The Mirror and the Light.Giles Ingram, Abbotsfordrsquos CEO, said: ldquoAbbotsford is delighted to be welcoming the Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival to the home of Sir Walter Scott, especially as we celebrate the th anniversary of his birth.ldquoThe authors and visitors to the festival will be able to experience the wonderful home and setting that inspired Scott to become Scotlandrsquos Greatest Storyteller and inspires writers still. It is fitting that in Scottrsquos anniversary year our commemorations include the opportunity to celebrate the literary heritage we enjoy today.Also attending the book festival are crime writer Val McDermid, former politician Ed Balls, Labour MP Ed Miliband, rugby star Gavin Hastings, and travel writer Michael Palin.Mr Moffat added: ldquoThe festival will feel a little dferent this year: we are swapping the warm, sunny days of June for the autumnal beauty of November and the iconic Harmony Garden for the magnicent home of Sir Walter Scott, Abbotsford.ldquoIt seems totally fitting in this year of the th celebrations of Scott to be welcoming a host of great authors to his home, but, on a practical note, holding the Book Festival at Abbotsford also allows us to ensure that the Festival is COVID-safe and that our audiences, whom we have missed so much, can come and enjoy everything we have to offer with peace of mind.ldquoAs ever, we are very grateful to our sponsors and funders for their continued support and are delighted to welcome on board this year as our media partner the Financial Times.ldquoWe very much look forward to ing to Harmony Garden in June , but, for now, we are thrilled to have so many wonderful authors joining us at Abbotsford this November for six days of unbridled literary pleasure.Discussions during the festival will also include Jonathan Dimbleby on how Hitler lost the war, political journalist Robert Peston on his new thriller The Whistleblower, and Pat Nevin on his autobiography The Accidental Footballer.The Family Book Festival will alsoover the weekend of November - with events suitable for youngsters aged three to .Borders author Alan Windram bringing the newest instalment of his One Button Benny series will join the childrenrsquos line-up, alongside Blue Peter award-winning author Pamela Butchart with her book A Monster Ate My Packed Lunch!, and illustrator Jill Calder and author Justin Davies will lead outdoor writing and drawing workshops.Tickets for this yearrsquos Borders Book go on sale todayfrom www.bordersbookfestival.org or by calling .

title: work-netherdale-stand-expected-start-soon
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has granted planning permission for a pound.m overhaul and upgrade of Gala Fairydean Rovers iconic stand at Netherdale.The structure, which was designed by modernist architect Peter Womersley almost  years ago, was one of the first in the UK to use a cantilever design.It was given category A status by Historic Environment Scotland in  and is an attraction with visitors to Galashiels.The work which is due to start in the next few weeks, includes cleaning and repairing all the concrete and resin will be applied to the roof area.Brick walls beneath the stand will be demolished and rebuilt, new glazing and ventilation added and turnstiles will be refurbished and ed to their original state.Chairman of Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club Community Trust Ross Buchan has played a major role in the restoration project over the last four years.He said: ldquoMy journey on the Stand Repair Project began in October . A Condition Survey Report issued during September  highlighted the need for repairs. This was brought to my attention, at a game at Netherdale, by then chairman and secretary of the Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club, Kevin Temple and Graeme McIver, respectively.ldquoI spoke with them the next again week when I volunteered my services to set up a working group to advance the work required in raising funding and addressing the commercial and technical challenges that such a repair project would present.ldquoThe lsquoArsquo Listed Stand is an example of the lsquobrutalistrsquo architectural style which emerged during the s in the United Kingdom, designed by architect Peter Womersley, a major contributor to the post-war development of the Scottish Borders.ldquoLike it or loath it, the stand is part of our architectural and historic heritage and itrsquos listing places a duty on us, the community, to preserve the structure for future generations.ldquoThe project has benefitted from work in cooperation and partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Historic Environment Scotland, Fallago Environmental Fund, Live Borders, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club Community Trust and our very experienced design team."We have reached a signicant stage on this journey, where this month, Scottish Borders Council granted planning permission, enabling the repairs works to proceed, together with theof tenders from contractors bidding to carry out the works. The design team is currently reviewing the tenders and hopes to appoint a contractor in the next few weeks with works programmed to commence on site in October . It is currently anticipated that completion of the works will be in August .

title: scottish-vaccine-passport-need-covid-vaccine-passport
story: Covid vaccine passports will be required in certain venues in Scotland from Friday October , as part of the governments plans to limit the spread of Covid over the winter months.The government proposed the use of vaccine passports earlier this month before it was voted through by MSPs in Parliament.It means that to enter certain social settings, adults over the age of  will need to provide evidence they have received both doses of the vaccine.People can order a letter with evidence of their jabs or alternatively download an app on their smartphones from September , which can be scanned on the door of events.Here are all the situations you will need a vaccine passport in Scotland from Friday...When will I need a vaccine passport in Scotland There are four situations in which you will require a vaccine passport in Scotland:nightclubsindoor live events with + people unseatedoutdoor live events with + peopleunseatedany event with ,+ peopleDuring her update on Tuesday, Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that the introduction of vaccine passports meant that all capacity limitations on venues would be lted.What qualies as a nightclub If all four of the following criteria are met by an institution, it will be considered a nightclub and will therefore be required to ask for proof of vaccine:open between midnight and amserves alcohol after midnightprovides live or recordedmusicfor dancinghas a designated space - which is actually in use - for dancingIf all four of these conditions apply to a venue, it will be considered as a nightclub and the vaccine passport scheme will therefore apply.Will my vaccine passport be checked from October  in these settings In theory, yes, you should be asked to show your vaccine passport in these settings from Friday.However, in Tuesdays update the First Minister confirmed that there would be a grace period for businessesuntil October , meaning there would be no enforcement action taken against businesses who dont comply with these rules before this date.

title: charitys-plea-held-fund-food-boxes-scottish-borders
story: CHARITY Food Train has declared the coming month BOXtober - launching a sponsorship drive to boost its work to ensure older people across the Borders do not go without leline shopping supplies.Iniduals and businesses are urged to sponsor boxes which carry leline shopping deliveries to older people in their homes in the region.The charity has launched a fundraising campaign, through which people can sponsor the boxes which carry essential groceries delivered to those who would otherwise struggle with shopping for just pound each.And, as part of the fundraising push throughout October, it is demonstrating how the support makes a dference to its shopping service volunteersrsquo work to ensure older people across the region do not go without vital supplies and le-enhancing social contact.Emma Black, Food Trainrsquos National Fundraising and Marketing Manager, said: ldquoTo sponsor a box may seem a simple act but it is one that genuinely makes a dference to our work, helping older people across the Borders to live healthier and better lives in their own homes.ldquoOur volunteers have never met more demand than they have in the past couple of years. The ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the lives of older people has highlighted the very real need for what we do - and how sponsoring our work makes a real dference.ldquoBOXtober has become a valuable part of our work to ensure we are best equipped to meet the demands we face.Last yearrsquos fundraiser exceeded expectations with just over  boxes across Scotland sponsored. The charity hopes for even more this time around.Each sponsored box, which will stay in the region where the pledge is made, will be labelled to recognise the donation for a year. Companies can also have their logos included.As part of its social media drive supporting BOXtober, Food Train is highlighting the facts that: pound will provide one new shopping delivery box, pound will buy a volunteerrsquos unorm, pound will buy a range of equipment valuable to ensuring deliveries are made and pound will provide enough fuel for  grocery deliveries.The BOXtober campaign comes as Food Train also seeks more volunteers. People can support its work by completing shopping lists in supermarkets or delivering them.To support the BOXtober campaign - or for more details - go to www.thefoodtrain sponsor-a-box.

title: crematorium-play-part-greener-environment
story: MELROSE crematorium is to officially reinforce its commitment to reduce the impact on the environment.Sirhowy Valley, which opened earlier this year, was the first crematorium in the UK to complete the new environmental compliance section of the Federation of Burial and Cremation Authorities inspection.But the Westerleigh Group who run Melrose say that this policy will be adopted in all of their  sites in Scotland, England and WalesAllan Jose said: ldquoEnvironmental issues are high on the agenda in almost every walk of le and had it not been for the pandemic, the environment and how we all might play our part in meeting the signicant challenges posed would probably have made the top slot.ldquoWesterleigh Group has already been playing a leading role in adopting environment-friendly practices which has been recognised by our colleagues across the UK.ldquoWersquore proud to be the first cremation authority in the UK to adopt the new Environmental Policy, which is a strong statement of intent from us about how we are determined to play our part to look after our precious planet.Westerleigh Group was the first large authority to adopt lsquoholding overrsquo coffins for cremation the following day and was among the first cremation authorities to withdraw the plastic polytainer for ashes in favour of recyclable cardboard.The group further strengthened its green credentials when it agreed to no longer allow the release of balloons or Chinese lanterns at its sites.The FBCA represents almost % of crematoria in the UK. Its President, Councillor David Marren, said: ldquoThe environment has always been an important part of the service our members provide to the bereaved as it plays an important role in supporting the grieving process.ldquoThe Environmental Policy Statement is to encourage members to focus more keenly on the environment, not only enhancing their grounds but operating in a manner which has minimal impact on the environment.Roger Mclaughlan, Chief Executive Officer of Westerleigh Group, said: ldquoWersquore all aware of the climate crisis and how everyone, from the biggest corporate businesses to iniduals, can play their part to be kinder to the environment. ldquoWesterleigh Group prides itself on having a very positive presence in every community where we have a crematorium and itrsquos natural that we would want to play our part in being greener and cleaner.ldquoWersquore very proud to be the first cremation authority in the UK to officially adopt the FBCA Environmental Policy Statement but wersquore not complacent we know there is a lot of work to do, and itrsquos going to take time.ldquoBut wersquove taken some very positive steps already and hope that other authorities in the sector will be equally committed to doing whatever we, as a collective industry, can do to protect our planet.

title: john-lamont-mp-show-support-dementia-research
story: TO MARK World Alzheimerrsquos Month, local MP John Lamont joined Alzheimerrsquos Research UK at an event in Parliament to show his support for dementia research. The aim of the event was to highlight the importance of the governmentrsquos manesto promise to double funding for dementia research.In the UK, nearly  million people are living with dementia, and it is one of the leading causes of death. It has a devastating impact on iniduals and their loved ones.Not only does dementia cause harm and heartbreak to millions of families, but it is also placing a huge strain on our health and social care system. The economic cost to the UK of caring for people with dementia is estimated to grow from poundbn in  to poundbn by .Historic global underinvestment means that while dementia research is making progress, it still lags far behind research into other major conditions.Mr Lamont was one of many MPs to meet with representatives from Alzheimerrsquos Research UK, as well as people impacted by the condition.John Lamont MP said: ldquoI was delighted to join Alzheimerrsquos Research UK to show my support for their work to help find preventions, treatments and, one day, a cure for dementia.ldquoMany people are living with dementia in the Borders, having a devastating impact on them and their families.ldquoIt is vital that we increase investment in dementia research to help make the progress needed to end the fear, harm and heartbreak caused by dementia.David Thomas, Head of Policy at Alzheimerrsquos Research UK, added: ldquoA big thank you to John for taking the time to join us and support dementia research during World Alzheimerrsquos Month.ldquoDementia is one of the biggest global health crises we face. In , the government made a manesto promise to double funding for dementia research to poundm a year and speed up progress in clinical trials. Now is the time to deliver on this pledge.ldquoThe response to COVID- has shown us what science can achieve with increased investment and momentum. And wersquore confident that, with the right support, we can make the le-changing breakthroughs that are so needed for people with dementia.

title: covid-passport-paper-copy-get-vaccine-passport-paper-form
story: With vaccine passports required in certain settings in Scotland from today, there are ious ways to show evidence of your vaccine status.Many people will choose to use theNHS Scotland Covid Status App which can be scanned to accessnightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with ,+ peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.However,you dont have a smartphone and cant access a digital copy of your vaccine status, dont worry - you can order a paper copy online or on the phone.Heres how to order a paper copy of your vaccine passport...How to order a paper copy of my vaccine passportYou can order a paper copy of your vaccine passport via your vaccine portal.To access your vaccine portal, you must register an account using your unique username.Your unique username can be found inthe letter, email or text youwere sent inviting you to attend your vaccine appointments.Once you have created an account, status of your vaccination can be found by selecting "vaccination status".On the bottom of the page, you can select "request a paper copy", which could take up to  days to arrive by post.Alternatively, you can order a paper copy by phoningthe specially designated Covid status helpline on  , open from am-pm every day.This paper copy, like theNHS Scotland Covid Status App, can be used for international travel and will include barcodes which can be scanned by venues.These barcodes areuneditable and usespecial ink to prevent forgery.Find out how to download theNHS Scotland Covid Status App here.

title: ryanair-now-fly-50-destinations-edinburgh-airport
story: RYANAIR is expanding its winter network from Edinburgh Airport with four new routes, Cork, Madrid, Palermo and Paris Beauvais. Thisbrings the total number of destinations served from the Scottish capital up to .The no-frills carrier announced the addition of winter routes to Knock, Tallinn, Shannon and Turin earlier in the summer.Fares are available at pound. one-way for travel until the end of March booked by midnight on Sunday.Marketing director Dara Brady said: ldquoRyanair remains committed to re-building Scotlandrsquos tourism industry and strengthening connectivity as Ryanair continues to grow in Europe and travel s to pre-pandemic level.ldquoAs Ryanair takes delivery of  Boeing - lsquoGamechangerrsquo aircraft this winter, we are delighted to announce these four new routes from Edinburgh on the back of the recent Scottish travel announcement ndash now operating a total of  routes.He reiterated a demand for Air Passenger Duty to be either scrapped or suspended ldquoto allow airlines quickly recover connectivity, jobs and tourism in the aftermath of the pandemic.Brady added: ldquoAPD makes Scottish airports very uncompetitive versus Europe, where Ryanair continues to add capacity, having opened a number of bases in recent months in the likes of Agadir, Zagreb, Billund, Stockholm, Riga and Turin.ldquoWhile Ryanair is committed to Scotland and its Edinburgh airport, the lack of government support continues to create further barriers to boosting traffic and growth.Edinburgh airport aviation director Kate Sherry said: ldquoWe know people need and want to travel and with restrictions easing, we want to provide as many options as possible for them to finally take that trip theyrsquove been waiting for.ldquoItrsquos clear to see there is confidence in the Edinburgh market as one for sustainable growth and it is good news that Ryanair are working with us to add new routes where possible and help peopleto travel safely.

title: cloich-wind-farm-plans-labelled-lunacy-community-leader
story: PLANS to install turbines in the Borders could muddy the waters for rural residents nearby, according to a community leader.Proposals to install  turbines at Cloich near Eddleston have been described as ldquolunacy by the villagersquos community council chairman, James Taylor.Mr Taylor, a resident of Stewarton for  years, says that the water supply that has served the community for centuries is under threat.ldquoOur primary concern remains the security of potable water for both quality and quantity for us and the other four dwellings at Stewarton and the livestock of about , herd of sheep and cattle on the farm around us, he said.:Borders woman admits biting police constable on the body during incidentldquoAll of us take our water off the hill, and itrsquos a mixture of surface water and groundwater.ldquoThis water comes from Stewarton Burn and from mosses and springs to the west of us, and thatrsquos from ground owned by Forestry and Land Scotland, which in turn is wholly owned by Scottish Ministers.EDF assured residents in May  that an avoidance approach would be used to protect the water supply.But Mr Taylor claims that EDF has not avoided risk to the water supply at the design stage and has chosen to rely on mitigation, post consent.He says that should the water be polluted or fail, the emergency response plan consists of supplying residents with bottled water in the short term, and bowser water in the long term.:Coronavirus: Herersquos how many new cases the Borders recorded in the last  hoursldquoThat to me is palpably ridiculous, despite EDF acknowledging that our shared water is at risk. Isolated inidual dwellings are the only group of people to hold EDFrsquos feet to the fire and demand from them and their advisors, a walkover of our water sources, that is why they have admitted risk, said Mr Taylor.He says businesses and dwellings to the east and west of Cloich, who also take their water off the hill, merit the same protection.He added: ldquoEDF has failed to understand our fragile rural infrastructure. To pour thousands of tonnes of concrete into a fragile water-bearing environment ndash that is lunacy.ldquoWhat happensthis doesnrsquot work is that many places Irsquove mentioned around Cloich will no longer be viable as dwellings, farms or businesses.Mr Taylor has criticised the research that government bodies have carried out, saying that they need to do ldquoa whole lot more.:Man, , found dead within Borders property, say policeThe original application in  was to install  turbines at m, but this received a raft of objections, including one from SBC, which sought and obtained a reduction in height to m on the grounds of unwanted and visual impact.However, the new application seeks to install a reduced number of  turbines, increased to .m in height.Mr Taylor says the turbines will be visible from Peebles, Edinburgh, Fe, and the south of Scotland.An EDF spokesperson said: ldquoThe final Cloich wind farm design is currently awaiting a decision from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Energy Consents Unit .:Man brandished baseball bat during Borders dispute with neighbours, court hearsldquoIt is based on feedback we received from a number of community groups and local people at our public exhibitions which were held in April this year and in February .ldquoAmongst others, Eddleston Community Council received a copy of the projectrsquos environmental impact assessment to allow them to consider the wind farm proposal carefully and make any comments to the ECU.ldquoIf consented we believe the wind farm will make an important contribution to meeting climate change targets and will establish a new benefit fund to support local community initiatives and activities.

title: virgin-money-scottish-branch-closing
story: Virgin Money has announced the closure of branches in Scotlanddue to fewer customers using the banks day-to-day.The former Clydesdale Bank branches are located across Scotland, with  more due to shut UK-wide from early next year.According to the bank, all the branches closing are located less than a third of a mile away from the nearest post office, although some people will be considerably further from another Virgin Money.The closures are expected to impact around  workers in Scotland, with the bank saying it will find alternative roles where possible.However, it has not ruled out potential redundancies.Here are the  branches closing in Scotland...Which Virgin Money branches are closing in Scotland The  Virgin Money branches closing in early  in Scotland are:AirdrieBanchoryBroughty FerryCumbernauldEast KilbrideGalashielsMilngavieMusselburghObanPortreeStenhousemuirWickFor people using the Portree branch, their nearest branchwill now be over  mile away in Fort William.Unite industrial officerDebbie Hutchings deemed the closures "shameful", adding:"The announcement will disproportionately impact on workers and communities across Scotland."Island communities from Portree to rural towns such as Wick are going to be left behind by Virgin Money."Our nations town centres, from Cumbernauld to Musselburgh, will be further hollowed out as fewer people will come into townthere is no bank branch."

title: covid-passport-paper-copy-get-vaccine-passport-paper-form
story: With vaccine passports required in certain settings in Scotlandfrom today, there are ious ways to show evidence of your vaccine status.Many people will choose to use theNHS Scotland Covid Status App which can be scanned to accessnightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.However,you dont have a smartphone and cant access a digital copy of your vaccine status, dont worry - you can order a paper copy online or on the phone.Heres how to order a paper copy of your vaccine passport...How to order a paper copy of my vaccine passportYou can order a paper copy of your vaccine passport via your vaccine portal.To access your vaccine portal, you must register an account using your unique username.Your unique username can be found inthe letter, email or text youwere sent inviting you to attend your vaccine appointments.Once you have created an account, status of your vaccination can be found by selecting "vaccination status".On the bottom of the page, you can select "request a paper copy", which could take up to -days to arrive by post.Alternatively, you can order a paper copy by phoningthe specially designated Covid status helpline on  , open from am-pm every day.This paper copy, like theNHS Scotland Covid Status App, can be used for internationaltravel and will include barcodes which can be scanned by venues.These barcodes areuneditable and usespecial ink to prevent forgery.Find out how to download theNHS Scotland Covid Status App here.

title: travel-rules-scotland-new-testing-rules-international-travel-uk
story: The travel rules in Scotlandare changing from Monday October , when new rules ontesting followinginternational travel will come into place.Scotland will join a four nation approach to internationaltravel, meaningno matter which of the four countries you are travelling to, the same rules will apply for each one.Nicola Sturgeon was initially hesitant to confirm that Scotlands rules would align with those of Westminster, however the first minister has since acknowledged that not doing so would put the Scottish travelindusry at a disadvantage.Heres everything you need to know about the rules on testing after international travel from Monday...What are the new rules on testing after international travel From Monday October , people who are fully vaccinated against Covid will no longer be required to take a pre-departure test when travelling to the UK fromnon-red listed countries.However, testing for travel to the UK has not been ruled out completely.People who are fully jabbed will still have to book and pay totake a test either on or before day  after they arrive.You will also be required to fill out a passenger locator form within-hours of your arrival.These rules for fully vaccinated people will alsoapply to those under , whether fully vaccinated or not.What rules on travel are being scrapped from Monday Despite the arrival tests staying in place, as of Monday October  the requirementfor a pre-departure test before travelling to the UKhasbeen scrapped for those who are fully vaccinated coming from non-red listed countries.What happensIm not fully
