title: 1%2C800 people on list for housing
story: THE enormity of the districtrsquos social housing crisis has been revealed this week.New figures published by the Housing Executive confirm that there are currently , people on the waiting list for public sector housing across Down District, with demand continuing to outstrip supply.Almost  per cent of those on the waiting list mdash , mdash are classed in the urgent need category, with the need particularly high in Downpatrick and Newcastle.Up until the end of March,  people had been allocated homes in Down District over the previous  months. The figure for the entire Newry, Mourne and Down Council area is .Housing chiefs confirmed that during the last financial year,  homes were completed across the local authority area and at the end of March,  new social homes were under construction, with plans to start work on building  more over the next three years.Homelessness also continues to be a major issue across the council area with , people not having a permanent home and Covid- being blamed on exacerbating this particular situation.During a special briefing session with councillors on Monday night, senior Housing Executive officials provided a detailed overview of the current waiting list and homelessness situation as they outlined details of the organisationrsquos work over the past  months and its future plans.They revealed that single, older persons and small family households comprise the majority of social housing applicants in the urgent need category across the district.Politicians say they are very aware of the need for more social housing and that the issue is the one most frequently raised with them by people from every corner of the district.Across the entire Newry, Mourne and Down Council area, there are currently , people on the waiting list for homes, with , in urgent need. The figures represent an increase of  and  respectively on the previous  months.Locally, the current waiting list figures reveal that  people are seeking social homes in Downpatrick, with  in the so-called urgent need category.In Newcastle, where a number of potential development sites have been identied,  people are on the waiting list, with  in urgent need. Last year, the number of homes allocated in both towns was  and  respectively.In Ballynahinch, there are  applicants on the waiting list, with  in the urgent need category.In the Castlewellan and Drumaroad area,  people are seeking homes, with  in urgent need, while there are  people on the waiting list for homes in Killyleagh and  in urgent need.In the Crossgar and Annacloy area,  people are on the waiting list with  in the urgent need bracket. Seventy three people are seeking social housing in the Ardglass, Ballyhornan and Dunsford area with  in urgent need, while in Saintfield  people are on the waiting list for a home with  in urgent need.In the Clough area, which includes Dundrum and Seaforde,  people are seeking social housing with  in urgent need, while  people are on the waiting list for a home in Strangford and Kilclief with the vast majority mdash  mdash in urgent need.The Housing Executive has confirmed that  people are on the waiting list for a home in Drumaness, with  classed in the urgent need category, while in Killough,  people are on the waiting list with  classed in urgent need, with  people seeking a home in Kilcoo. It was also confirmed that less than  people are on the waiting list for social housing in Annsborough, Shrigley, Kilmore and Spa areas.Addressing councillors on Monday evening, Housing Executive chief executive Grainia Long reflected on an ldquounprecedented year and said that Covid- had presented ldquohuge challenges for the organisation.She said staff moved staff out of offices to work at home, while lockdown restrictions and supply issues meant a backlog in tacking repairs and delays in much-needed upgrade schemes on estates.She said almost poundm was invested in new-build accommodation in the district, which saw  housing starts getting underway, while housing completions for the year were , despite the pandemic.She continued: ldquoWe provided pound, in grant funding to support local groups in Newry, Mourne and Down, across several funding streams, including our community grants, community safety, areas at risk and community cohesion programmes. We also supported  people experiencing homelessness in the last year.ldquoGiven the necessity to social distance the hostels in Newry, Mourne and Down, this situation placed enormous pressure on temporary accommodation in the district and as we emerge from the pandemic, our reset plan, The Way Home, has been fully funded by the Department for Communities..prettyPhoto

title: Ahoy%2C matey as children enjoy play ship
story: CHILDREN at the Little Acorns cross-community pre-school in the grounds of Derryboy Primary School have been learning the ropes of their new outdoor pirate play ship.The Jolly Friendship has been provided by the Energy for Children Charitable Trust to help boost the schoolrsquos outdoor play equipment.Established in  to provide a play-based learning environment for children, Little Acorns is a self-funded pre-school which supports  children from the Crossgar, Saintfield and Killyleagh areas and families from across the community.With imaginative play critical for creative development and wellbeing, Little Acorns has been working to grow its outdoor facilities to enhance the learning experience and opportunities for the children attending, but needed a funding boost to get the project started.Michelle Mullan, from the pre-schoolrsquos management committee, says outdoor play is important for young children in their personal development as well as their educational experience.ldquoIt encourages them to explore, get active, use their imagination and stimulate their senses through touching, hearing, seeing and feeling, something which has been more important than ever over the last  months, she explained.ldquoWith the support of the Energy for Children Charitable Trust, we have installed a new wooden pirate ship which will be the lsquoanchorrsquo for our outdoor play space which we will continue to grow as our fundraising allows.Michelle said said the pre-school is grateful to the charitable trust for its support and for enabling Little Acorns to develop a space for the children to enjoy, play with their friends and learn.The charityrsquos liaison officer, Gillian Orr, said it is pleased to see how much of a dference the funding has made to the entire community at Little Acorns which is providing a much-needed service to the local community.ldquoThis is exactly why the charity exists, to help local children who are most in need and to provide facilities and equipment to make things better for them, Gillian added.Energy for Children is a Phoenix Natural Gas initiative and that of the wider natural gas industry. It was established in  to provide financial support to groups and iniduals that may slip through the net of the wider charity network.Founded on the principle that all monies raised go directly to local children and young people, the charitable trust aims to reach deeper into the heart of local communities throughout Greater Belfast and beyond in order to really make a dference to disadvantaged childrenrsquos lives.Since its formation, the trust has helped over , local children and continues to help those who need it most.More information about the charitable trust is available at www.phoenixnaturalgas about-us phoenix-group corporate-responsibility..prettyPhoto

title: Ardglass chemist Paula retires after 31 years
story: AN Ardglass woman has bid an emotional farewell to the community ahead of her retirement after  years of service in the area.Paula McDaid, owner of McDaidrsquos Chemist, hosted a marquee reception last week as a thank you to her many loyal customers.Paula says although it has not been an easy decision the time is now right for her to retire from the business and move on.ldquoI want to thank my customers, for their loyalty and support throughout my  years as the pharmacist in Ardglass, she said.ldquoItrsquos been an amazing journey with a lot of laughs, meeting many colourful and ied characters who I have built up relationships with along the way.ldquoIt was lovely to see everyone at the marquee and Irsquom so thankful for their kind comments and well wishes.She added: ldquoI also wish to extend thanks to Fiona McMullan, Ciara Van Vogt and Barbara Emerson who supplied the food at the event for everyone to enjoy. It all went down a treat.Paula took over the reins of the pharmacy from her late father, Thomas McDaid, who was initially based in Kildare Street before moving to Castle Place three years later.This was when Paula joined her father in the pharmacy and she enjoyed  successful working years there before relocating once more to the Downpatrick Road ndash where it has cemented its place as a cornerstone of the village.Paula has poignantly decided that her last day behind the counter will be tomorrow mdash the same date as her fatherrsquos birthday, in what she describes as ldquoclosing off a circle.She said: ldquoThe Downpatrick Road premises will turn  years old on the date I retire. We opened it on my fatherrsquos nd birthday and I will say my goodbyes on what would have been his th birthday.ldquoI didnrsquot initially plan for that, but when I realised I could say a farewell on such a signicant date I thought it was fitting.Local people have also been reassured that the same members of staff will continue working in the establishment under the new owners, McKeevers Chemists.ldquoI would like to thank my staff for their loyalty, dedication and hard work, particularly through this particularly challenging time of Covid-. I couldnrsquot have done it without them, said Paula.ldquoAll the staff are still there and they will not be changing. Some of the members have been there as long as  years, theyrsquore like family to me.ldquoWersquove all grown up around the shop and itrsquos something I will miss but it means I can do things I have given a back seat to due to running a business.A long standing member of Ardglass Golf Club, she revealed how she missed being able to do the things she used to do freely before she took over the business.ldquoItrsquos a bitter-sweet feeling, and something which I am very emotional over. On the one hand I know I will miss the pharmacy dearly, but on the other hand I will get to enjoy my golf again and have time to myself, she said.A former competitor in the New York Marathon, she says she is looking forward to ldquoexciting new challenges.She added: ldquoWhen we are free to travel again I want to be able to grab those types of dferent opportunities with both hands..prettyPhoto

title: Carryduff too much for Saul
story: SENIOR football championship finalists Carryduff against Intermediate champions Saul was the game at Liatroim as the SFC entered Round .Carryduff arrived after a defeat to RGU and with Saul losing to Burren, both sides wanted the win to avoid a relegation battle and stay in the Senior Championship next year.Carryduff got off to a great start with club captain Joe McFlynn scoring the opening point from play after winning the throw in.Saul quickly responded with a great play of holding the ball for Ruari OrsquoHare to get his sidersquos first point of the game. Carryduffrsquos James Guinness found a gap through the Saul back line and this was followed up by Daniel Guinness in the sixth minute.Ciaran Harney took a great finish to the ball to pull a point back for Saul before the home sidersquos Ruari OrsquoHare and Josh Connery were both booked.Michael McGrath got Carryduffrsquos fourth point of the game, but it was the quick pace of Philip Doran in the th minute that saw Saul get a goal and show they were up for the fight.The visitors dug deep before the first water break with Cian Clinton getting a set of points and Sean McGonigle, but Saulrsquos Lorcan Harney and Danny Curran both got on the scoreboard and at the first water break it was level, Carryduff - v - Saul.The next  minutes was very much Carryduff pushing forward, with Daniel Guinness and Michael McGrath adding a further two points each to their tallies, but it was the goal from club captain, McFlynn, that pushed Carryduff ahead.James Mahoney got Saul a point, but then got a black card, reducing Saul to  men. Half time Carryduff - v - Saul with Carryduff carrying a comfortable eight-point lead into the second half.Saulrsquos Ciaran Harney quickly got a point on the board and it looked like Carryduff were sitting back a bit, as Ciaran added to Saulrsquos score again which came from a free.Carryduffrsquos management team worked hard to get their men back into the game and it was not until the th minute of the second half that the visitors Carryduff got back into scoring ways, with Michael McGrath, which was followed up by additional three points, two from frees taken by McFlynn and the third from Cian Clinton.With this run of points, it was dficult to see how Saul would close the gap, but it was Philip Doran who again powered through the Carryduff back line to get his second goal of the game. Ciaran Harney got his fourth point just before the second water break.With the score Carryduff -Saul - , it was all to play in the last  minutes of the game.McFlynn scored a free in the th minute to extend Carryduffrsquos lead and Sean McGonigle added to that d in the nd minute.Saul were throwing everything at the game and it paid off with Lorcan Harney and Jack Fitzsimons both bagged a point apiece. In the th minute Carryduff finished the game with a goal through Michael McGrath, and added another goal in the th minute.Carryduff move into the next round as Saul wait to see who they will face in the relegation battle.Saul -Carryduff -SFC ND ROUND.prettyPhoto

title: Cathal aiming for climate success
story: A DOWN High School student is hoping to win a prize of euro, to hold a climate change camp for local young conservationists.Cathal Quinn, a Year  pupil at the Downpatrick Grammar School, is a youth leader with Lecale Conservation Association, a voluntary community group dedicated to safeguarding the natural and built heritage of the area.The group restores local beach sand dune systems, turns wasteland into mini forests or community gardens and campaigns for environmental causes.During the summer, Cathal was involved in ious projects with the group, one of which was a plan to create a series of climate change camps for young adults to identy and influence the decision makers in their own local government, planning departments and education system.Cathal and his friends, who attend a range of local high schools, entered their project into a competition for funding for such initiatives run by Coca-Cola across the island of Ireland.They successfully passed the preliminary stages of the competition and are now shortlisted to win a prize of euro, which would enable them to run the Climate Change Camps.Down High School is asking for local support to help Cathal and his project win the top prize, so that they can put their Climate Change Ideas into action.To vote visit: https:www.coca-cola.ie community thank-you-fund vote.prettyPhoto

title: Champs Kilcoo reach last eight
story: A DECENT crowd gathered in Pairc Esler for this local derby between Kilcoo and Clonduff in the second round of the Senior Championship.In the end, it was the Magpies who progressed to the quarter-finals, while Clonduff face Warrenpoint a round three knockout game this weekend to be in with a chance of reaching the same stage.This game wonrsquot be remembered as one of the greats but it was exciting due to the closeness on the scoreboard, even though for long spells scores were hard to come by.The Yellows made the better start, with Ross Carr opening the scoring. By the water-break, bizarrely, Kilcoo hadnrsquot registered a score with Clonduff leading - to -.However, on  minutes a Jerome Johnston free finally got his side off the mark and just three minutes later he did what he does best ndash found the net to send Kilcoo into the lead.After Jeromersquos brother Ryan had rattled the crossbar for a second time, Johnston was first to pounce to send the Magpies into the lead.Ceilum Doherty and Eugene Branagan put Kilcoo three clear before half time but Clonduff managed to reduce the deficit to one thanks to some good scoring from Arthur McConville and Eamon Brown.Clonduffrsquos Tom Close was black carded on the stroke of half time, leaving the yellows a man down for the first  minutes of the second half.This didnrsquot seem to matter as they caught Kilcoo out of position straight after the break, with Jayme Gribben finding the net for Clonduff.Mickey Moranrsquos team again responded and by the end of the third quarter it was - apiece with mistakes and turnovers aplenty in the game.Dylan Ward and Tiernan Fettes were introduced for the county champions for the closing stages and both made a dference to give their team much-needed energy.Going down the final stretch Kilcoo led by two, Shealan Johnston, Ceilum Doherty and the brilliant Ryan Johnston all on target.Aidan Carr and a Stephen McConville free kept the Hilltown men within range but it was their neighbours who finished stronger as Shealan Johnston and Miceal Rooney closed the scoring leaving the Magpies victorious.Despite Kilcoo playing nowhere near to their potential, they still managed to grind out a result and with Darryl Branagan, Niall McEvoy, Paul Devlin and a fully fit Dylan Ward set toto the starting lineup, they will fancy their chances of pushing on for a th county title.Ciaran McBride will rue the missed chances his team spurned, especially a late goal opportunity, in a game that was refereed excellently by Brendan Rice.Kilcoo: M McCourt, N Branagan, R McEvoy , A Morgan, A Branagan, A Branagan, M Rooney , P Greenan, A Morgan, C Doherty , S Johnston , E Branagan , C Laverty, R Johnston , J Johnston .Subs used: T Fettes, D Ward and J Clarke.Clonduff: P Gribben, L Branagan, D OrsquoHagan, T McEvoy, P Branagan, C Carr, J Gribben , R Carr , A Carr , T Close, P OrsquoHagan, B OrsquoHagan, A McConville , S McConville , E Brown .Subs used: J OrsquoHagan, P Wilson, S McGreevy and T McGreevy.Referee: Brendan Rice Kilcoo -Clonduff -SFC ND ROUND.prettyPhoto

title: Consultation to help boost Downpatrick
story: THE business community in Downpatrick is to be consulted about what measures could be taken to support its continued regeneration and development at a time when there are  empty shop units across the town.Local council officials are behind the initiative after Newry, Mourne and Down Council recently debated potentially appointing a new town centre manager.While no final decision has been taken on appointing someone, the local authority wants to gauge the view of businesses on what they view as the priority moving forward post-Covid.The global pandemic hit a number of local businesses hard and while there are some politicians in favour of appointing a town centre manager to work in Downpatrick, others believe that the county town should not be given preferential treatment.Plans to speak with traders comes on the back of a recent proposal by Cllr Gareth Sharvin when the town centre manager issue was discussed at a meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee.Cllr Sharvin expressed concern about the number of empty business premises which includes three former banks which have been lying vacant for a number of years.The Downpatrick councillor said there are eight empty units at the Grove shopping centre in Market Street, three in Market Lane, alongside many others dotted around the town.ldquoLocal councillors recently met with Economic, Regeneration and Tourism officers to discuss theway forward in identying the best mechanism to support and move Downpatrick forward, revealed Cllr Sharvin.ldquoMy SDLP colleagues and I sees the revitalisation of Downpatrick as offering a unique opportunity to ensure that the town is ready to meet the opportunities of a post-Covid society. One of the most effective ways of identying how we meet these needs is consulting with our existing business stakeholders who have invested into our town and community.Cllr Sharvin said the proposed consultation will focus on the business communityrsquos view on what is positive about the work the local authority currently does.ldquoIt will also seek to find out what the organisation does not do so well, what businesses want to see in terms of support and what steps can be taken to attract additional investment, he continued.ldquoGiven Downpatrickrsquos rich and vibrant history, we have visitors coming from all over the world to visit St Patrickrsquos final resting place and complementing this is a fantastic array of attractions such as Inch Abbey, the St Patrick Centre, Downpatrick and Co Down Railway, Ballydugan medieval site, Struell Wells and Saul Church.ldquoHowever, the last thing I want is for those who visit the town and experience all this to then move on to Newry or Belfast.Cllr Sharvin said it is important that there are facilities for visitors to stay to have a meal and even remain in the town overnight.ldquoThis is something that I and my colleagues would like to see delivered which would have a positive,ripple effect on delivering a nightle that we can be proud of, he remarked.He said he believes that a town centre manager or a chamber of commerce could be the right mechanism to bring the town together and play a proactive role in attracting investment and new business to the area.He added: ldquoWe have to get the right blend of making Downpatrick attractive not only to tourists but, just as importantly, to residents who live and work in the area.ldquoI would urge all businesses to engage in the council survey and highlight what they would like to see in the Downpatrick area. It also important that they spell out how the local authority can support them to grow and make Downpatrick a top location for people to visit, stay and spend..prettyPhoto

title: Four goals for Luke
story: BALLYNAHINCH Olympic Town made the journey to Mountain Quarter hoping to find their first win of the season.They were up against a Ballynagross side who was coming into the match full of confidenc,e having not lost a match so far this season.For the first  minutes it was a close encounter, but Ballynagross found their feet and scoring ways.Luke Shields was the standout performer for the lsquoGross, finding the back of the net on four separate occasions.Philip Doran, Connor Marron, Shea McComiskey and Kieran Taggart made up the rest of the tally in what was a resounding win.Ballynahinch had their opportunities, but Ballynagross felt secure with Cathail Arnold in goal.If Ballynagross continue in this fashion they will be fighting it out for the league title, while Ballynahinch need to find a winning run of form soon to get out of the relegation battle.Ballynagross Ballynahinch Olympic Town NEWCASTLE LEAGUE PREMIER.prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C October 3%2C 2001
story: BISHOPSCOURT ndash Bishopscourt motor racing circuit is for sale, it has been confirmed this week.A series of adverts have been placed in national newspapers outlining the scale and potential of the sprawling complex.The Recorder understands the move has already attracted signicant interest among potential buyers, with no less than four firm bids already lodged.Last month, the Northern Bank changed the locks on the gates of the major complex after months of intense speculation surrounding its future and local planning officials announced they were considering taking legal action because the owners had exceeded the number of race meetings they were allowed to run.The current owner of the circuit, Mr David Beattie, confirmed yesterday afternoon that the complex is for sale, but he revealed he is currently working on a rescue package which he hopes will allow him to retain sole control.It has also emerged that he is due to meet shortly with Stormont Ministers Sam Foster and Michael McGimpsey to discuss his plans for the race circuit.DUNDRUM ndash Sectarian vandals caused thousands of pounds worth of damage to Dundrum Gaelic Football Club during a weekend arson attack.A UVF slogan was brandished on the near-completed building before it was set alight on Saturday evening.Damage to the building, which it is estimated will cost the club thousands of pounds to repair, included broken windows and burnt door frames.The fire had gone out before the incident was uncovered shortly before am on Sunday.Police this week confirmed that the fire had been started ldquomaliciously but said they were keeping an open mind about the perpetrators who they believe may have been youths.Club secretary Jarlath Carey said the arson attack was unusual for the club.ldquoWe have good relations with other sporting groups in the town, he said. ldquoThere is a certain amount of cross-community co-operation and that makes this incident surprising.NEWCASTLE ndash Traders campaigning for specialist closed circuit security cameras to be installed in Newcastle have been told the initial bill alone could stretch to pound,.The startling figure was revealed to some of the townrsquos businessmen and women during a meeting of Newcastle Chamber of Commerce earlier this week.The group, which has been lobbying for the seven cameras to be set up along the resortrsquos Main Street, has priced the system but warned thatthe scheme does go ahead it will be some years down the line.The Chamber carried out a survey during the summer, asking traders and residentsthey thought the cameras would be a benefit to the town.Revealing that there was ldquo per cent support, for the system from respondents, the Chamberrsquos president Peter Law, told members that the installation of the cameras would ldquoinevitably reduce ious crimes which have a times given the town a reputation.CLOUGH ndash A mobile telecommunications company has announced its intention to erect a mobile telephone mast in Clough.BT Cellnet has this week advertised plans to erect a . metre mast at Watsonrsquos Garagein Clough, as well as a radio base station at the Downpatrick Telephone Exchange at Church Street.The proposals have led local anti-mast campaigners to urge communities to take action before the equipment is installed close to local houses and offices.Martine Fulcher, who helped form the group People Against Masts in Bryansford earlier this summer, this week said people should be made more aware of the potential health issues related to living near such masts.ldquoOnly when I went to a public meeting and heard somebody talk about the risks of these masks could I make an informed decision about not wanting them near my children and home.DOWNPATRICK ndash Senior officials from the Downpatrick Property Trust have detailed their plans for the regeneration of a number of derelict buildings in the town.During a special briefing session with local politicians last week, Trust officials spelt out their development plans for premises at English Street and at Breenrsquos Corner.They explained their plans will result in the provision of several new shops and a number of town centre apartments.The grouprsquos chairman, Mr Cecil Maxwell, said that since the Trust was established in , it has worked closely with both the Department of Environment and Down Council, to make both groups fully aware of its plans.A number of local councillors have recently been critical of the Trustrsquos plans to redevelop Breenrsquos Corner, suggesting that the building should instead be bulldozed to help improve town centre traffic flow by widening the Irish Street Market Street junction.But following last weekrsquos meeting they have accepted that bulldozing the building is not an option and that responsibility for addressing the townrsquos traffic chaos is a matter for the Roads Service.BALLYNAHINCH ndash The man spearheading the campaign for a Ballynahinch by-pass, has called for increased political pressure to drive the initiative forward.Mr Francis Casement said the congestion in the town is getting progressively worse and fearsthe by-pass is not addressed more urgently by politicians, traffic could grind to a halt.Over the past number of months, he has been working closely with regeneration officials and members of the townrsquos business community and a series of meetings have already been held in progress the issue.Stormont Minister Gregory Campbell visited the town last year to view the scale of the traffic problem at first hand, but Mr Casement says that since then, very little progress has been made.Mr Casement has suggested that children from local schools could be asked to get involved in a major cross-community project and carry out traffic surveys at all the main approach roads to the town.Mr Casement said while Ballynahinch struggles to make headway to secure the pound.m funding to build the new by-pass linking the townrsquos Newcastle and Belfast roads, development of a new poundm by-pass in Comber is only weeks away.KILLINCHY ndash Tourism officials have been given a sneak preview of a major new holiday complex which is set to provide the local economy with a major boost.The first of  purpose-built holiday cottages at Hazelwood Glen at Lisbane near Killinchy was publicly launched last week and has been given the thumbs up by both the tourist industry and local politicians.From next Easter, holidaymakers will be able to stay in the homes which have been furnished to a high standard and constructed to comply with five-star self-catering guidelines.Each comes with central heating, three ensuite bedrooms, log burning fire and all the usual equipment which people expect in modern accommodation.Outside, each cottage has its own barbecue, with  acres of newly landscaped park land providing the perfect back. A pitch and putt course also forms part of the development, in tandem with new tennis courts.A series of walkways have also been created throughout the development and running alongside them is a wildle pond and wildflower meadow.Holidaymakers also have a spectacular view over the international acclaimed Strangford Lough, which is less than a mile away.CASTLE ESPIE ndash Every year thousands of Brent geese complete an epic ,km journey from Canada to Strangford Lough, arriving in huge flocks in late autumn.Next Saturday and Sunday the National Trust and the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust, will host a series of Brentwatching for Beginners sessions at Castle Espie, so that members of the public can get a close look at one of the greatest spectacles of local wildle.Around , geese have arrived at Strangford Lough since the beginning of September and those figures look set to rise in the coming weeks.Although there will be thousands of Brent geese there should also be opportunities to see other species of wildfowl and waders such as dunlin, knot, curlew and oyster-catcher..prettyPhoto

title: Full steam ahead at railway
story: AFTER an absence of over  months, the first train of the Downpatrick and County Down Railwaysnaked its way through the countryside out to Inch Abbey.Itrsquos not full steam yet however for the transport charity, as the runs were for driver re-familiarisation following a long period in mothballs.Railway chairman Robert Gardiner said: ldquoWhilst wersquove been keeping our locomotives and railcars ticking over at regular intervals to keep them in good order, we need to do a few refreshers to get people back in the swing of operating them.He explained that throughout the lockdown period, DCDR had been carrying out signicant work on the track between Downpatrick and Inch Abbey, which has seen every joint unbolted and lubricated, rails changed, signage erected, and track geometry improved in anticipation of reopening.Mr Gardiner continued: ldquoThe first train out of the gates for nearly two years was former NIR  Class railcar, with a number of runs along our Inch Abbey line took place through the sunny Sunday afternoon as drivers Norman and Mike reacquainting themselves with the controls of this classic diesel railcar, familiar to many who used to commute to work from the mid s onwards, and as the Coffee Carriages parked at Inch Abbey.ldquoBoth railcar and drivers performed brilliantly. It was a pretty special moment travelling out to Inch Abbey for the first time in nearly two years, and then watching the railcar travelling backwards and forwards through the beautul Quoile basin was just incredible.Depending on Covid restrictions, the railway hopes to welcome passengers back and open the doors to the station again.Mr Gardiner added: ldquoWersquore aiming to get back in action for Christmas this year, subject to government restrictions and guidance, although we havenrsquot quite figured out the details..prettyPhoto

title: Helping residents living in social isolation
story: LAST month I launched my mental health initiative for Newry, Mourne and Down Council around the impact of rural isolation.Across the district, the geographical range that our constituents span is monumental in comparison to our population. That being said, it is no wonder that our rural communities may feel isolated from our bigger towns and cities, where investment and opportunities are more obvious.Rural isolation is closer to all of us than we realise exploring this topic brought to light my own childhood memories of growing up in the countryside.While I loved my upbringing, I hadnrsquot considered how it was impacted by the fact that I grew up in a rural area. It was through exploring the topic of rural isolation that I realised the social effects it can have on our youth.My own children are growing up in the countryside as well and I can now see how this may impact them socially they are not playing with friends in the evenings like many would in housing developments and built up areas.They are playing with each other in their own garden, similar to my own experience. While I donrsquot think this is a negative thing for my children, due to the volume of social groups and clubs that they participate in, I am now consciously taking opportunities to expose them to a wider iety of social situations, so they do not feel the potential effects of rural isolation.It is clear to see the effects of rural isolation when just recently at a meeting with Translink, the cutting of rural bus routes and services was brought to light. This is another slap in the face to those living in rural areas without access to their own vehicle, especially when considering the climate crisis.I and my fellow councillors and party colleagues are encouraging constituents to use active travel and public transport.Meanwhile, those exact services are being cut removing the option for active travel. This is not good enough.I have conducted a range of investigative meetings to see how groups and organisations within South Down in particular are taking action to prevent rural isolation.I recently met with Nicholas McCrickard, manager of Co Down Rural Community Network, an organisation crucial in combatting rural isolation in South Down as itrsquos an umbrella body set up and managed by community groups in the area for more than  years.The aim of the organisation is to create an inclusive future where all citizens actively participate in local le which stimulates a vibrant society.Nicholas and his team, with the support of community groups, ensure regular outreach to all of the citizens in the area so that they can enhance their own lives through participation with ious organisations. This stimulation is a sure-fire way to combat rural isolation, but the resources need to be available to ensure no one is left behind.I recently visited the offices of Good Morning Down in Downpatrick mdash another vital service many in our community rely on. It is an organisation which regularly makes telephone calls to those facing isolation for a iety of reasons. These calls are a method of friendship building between volunteers and residents of a wide iety of ages.The youngest volunteer in Good Morning Down is in their late s, while the eldest is in their late s. Nearly  years worth of knowledge and experience will be exchanged through these conversations and I walked away from this meeting, feeling truly touched by the dedication of the staff and volunteers.In addition, having met with Womenrsquos Aid in recent days, fresh in my mind are the stories of the impact that living in a rural setting has on many women who are isolated from much of society.Not having that friendly neighbour close by can impact the severity of abusive relationships. Thankfully, we have organisations such as Womenrsquos Aid who recognise this and work every day with women in these situations, but funding, resourcing and legislation is always an issue.These are only a few of the fantastic initiatives that offer support to those in rural communities, however, there are many who are unaware of their operation.I would like to raise awareness of the services available to our rural constituents, to promote inclusivity and encourage a positive approach to mental health and wellbeing. It is extremely important to raise awareness and encourage our rural communities to stop and think about their mental health and to consider how rural isolation may affect them.I would encourage our rural communities to take time out to improve their mental health, normalise discussion around issues of isolation and avail of local mental health services.It is time that Newry, Mourne and Down Council took responsibility and recognise the vital work local groups within our community do for the residents of our district and remember that ratepayers donrsquot just live in our major towns like Downpatrick, but also in rural areas such as the wider Lecale countryside.There needs to be a serious refocusing on service provision in rural areas and a renewed approach to capital investment. We need to stand up for the safety of our rural communities, and protect them from the effects of isolation. Rural communities cannot continue to be left behind..prettyPhoto

title: Horse show fundraiser for Uganda
story: THE organisers of Saintfield Horse Show handed over a cheque for pound, at a reception at Temple Golf and Country Club last Thursday evening.The money was raised at the show which was held at Danescroft Equestrian Centre, near Lisburn, on Saturday, August .Last year money raised from the horse show and the Saintfield Christmas Charity Ride provided a borehole for a village in Uganda, giving the community fresh, clean water.Show director Joan Cunningham said: ldquoNow wersquore committed to continue making a massive dference by providing a maize milling machine which will enable the farmers to process their crops for food. This will also cut out the middleman, thus allowing for their incomes to increase sustainably. The  Saintfield Christmas Charity Santa Ride will take place on Saturday, December .For more details contact Joan Cunningham on   or email joancunningham@gmail website www.saintfieldhorseshow..prettyPhoto

title: It’s heating up
story: THE temperature is rising in this yearrsquos Down football championships as teams enter the make or break knockout stages of their respective competitions.Despite a cagey opening quarter of their second round local derby, reigning senior champions Kilcoo managed to successfully overcome neighbours Clonduff and progress to the quarter-finals.Mickey Moranrsquos men will concede they were off the pace at Paacuteirc Esler, but with a number of regular starters set toin time for the next round, the Magpies will surely be a dreaded draw for anyone in the competition.Meanwhile, Aidan Robinsonrsquos Downpatrick dark horses made it two wins from two after defeating Longstone by eight points on Saturday.Downpatrick have made a resounding impact in this yearrsquos Senior Championship thus far after dispatching last yearrsquos runners-up Carryduff in their opener, before following that up with their latest scalp at the weekend.Longstone were entering the tie on a high after defeating Warrenpoint in the first round, who many had claimed would push Kilcoo all the way.Both of Downpatrickrsquos previous opponents, Carryduff and Longstone, will now meet in the third round of the competition where one will progress to the quarters and the other will see their championship title hopes shattered.Carryduff managed to bounce back from their opening round loss with a good win against newly promoted Saul.Last yearrsquos intermediate football champions could be excused for their back-to-back defeats in this seasonrsquos top flight campaign after they were drawn the vastly experienced Burren followed by the Carryduff side.However, Saul now enter the relegation battle and face the possibility of ing to the intermediate ranks that they fought so valiantly to climb out of last year.Joining them in the fight for survival will be Loughinisland who, similarly to their opening round, could not maintain their lead for the full duration of the match as they lost to Mayobridge.The Bridge now face Bredagh in their third round tie, after the Belfast side defeated Castlewellan in their opener but failed to beat Ballyholland to progress to the quarters.Castlewellan will be relieved that their one point victory over Rostrevor at the weekend kept their Championship dreams alive, but they will face stf opposition against Glenn in the qualying round.Also in the depths of relegation are Bryansford, who lost out to Glenn in their opener before they were defeated by Warrenpoint in the second round.In the intermediate action, Liatroim made it two consecutive wins to progress to the quarters after they defeated Darragh Cross by five points.The Cross will now meet Newry Shamrocks via the back door route with nothing other than a win requiredthey are to keep their promotion to the Senior Championship alive.Whereas it was a bitter pill to swallow for Dromara, Bright and St Johnrsquos who all tasted defeat for the second game in a row and now face the dreaded relegation battle.Despite Dromara losing to Saval in their second round, they will feel more disappointed at their opening performance where they should have secured the win over Clann na Banna after leading for long durations of the contest.Simarly, Bright will also be kicking themselves after they blew a nine point lead in their opener against Tullylish before they lost out to St Paulrsquos.St Johnrsquos also had their promotion hopes dashed in heartbreaking fashion after they lost their must-win game against Newry Shamrocks by just one point.In the Junior Championship, Kilclief ensured Teconnaught would remain in the competition for another year after a three point win progressed the red and green side to the next round.Teconnaught lost out to Aughlisnafin in their opener whilst this was Kilcliefrsquos first taste of championship action after they received a bye in the first round.Elsewhere, Ardglass bounced back from their opening round lost to Dundrum with a fantastic win over Aghaderg.All of the quarter-final teams will have to await the results of the next round before their opponents are known..prettyPhoto

title: Musical garden party raises hundreds for local charities
story: THE recent musical charity garden party organised by the Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Twinning Group raised pound, for five local charities.Hosted by Mr Hugh and Mrs Violet Hawthorne at their Diary Lake House at Old Belfast Road in Ballynahinch, the event was a great success and was favoured with fine weather.Over  people attended the garden party which is the th to be hosted by the local couple, with guests enjoying afternoon tea and treated to a number of superb performances.Musical performers included the Alastair Scott Ceilidh Band, Sam Gill and his sons Jack and Charlie from Hollymount Pipe Band with music and melodies provided by Mr Gerry Walsh, Mr Brian and Mrs Monica Megoran and the Ballygowan Community Choir.Dotted around the garden, guests were able to engage with local artists who presented their creative displays which included painting, wood turning, gt cards and flower arranging.In addition, children enjoyed creative story telling by Pamela Dickson and Antoinette Campbell from Ballynahinch library.The raffle and auction of many ied and valuable prizes was a great success and contributed to the enjoyment of the day.The Twinning Group would like to thank Montalto Estate, the Primrose Bar and Restaurant, Drumlins Restaurant, Temple Golf Club, Thomas Kellyrsquos, Stewart and Gibson, McCoubreyrsquos Electrical, Kitchen Master, Joseph Morrowrsquos gents outfitters, Z-Cut, Watsonrsquos Flower Shop, Bennettyrsquos Fish and Chips, Cuts both Ways, EuroSpar Drumaness, AJC Group Downpatrick, Gordonrsquos Chemist, Vivo Extra, Carlisle Fresh Foods, Eamonn McAuley Interior Design, the Autogrid and Magowan Fashions for their generous donations, prizes and vouchers.ldquoWe are pleased that we raised a total of pound, at the garden party, said Twinning Group chairwoman Karen Patterson.ldquoThe money raised will be donated to our five chosen charities this year which are Ballynahinch Counselling Services, Northern Ireland Chest Heart and Stroke, Northern Ireland Alzheimerrsquos Society, Air Ambulance NI and Diabetes NI.Ms Patterson said the cheques will be presented to the ious organisations over the coming weeks.ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who in any way supported the recent event, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Pro IRA graffiti blasted
story: A LOCAL politician has branded those responsible for daubing pro-IRA graffiti on a bridge bear Dundrum as ldquoidiotic.Slieve Croob councillor Alan Lewis believes the culprits have demonstrated what he described as an ldquounfortunate increase in bigotry and said it is beyond him why ldquosomeone would be so stupid.The graffiti was daubed on a section of the Moneycarragh bridge mdash also known locally as Bennettrsquos bridge mdash with Cllr Lewis saying what happened was ldquoidiotic and void of reason and that defacing the historic bridge demonstrated ldquoovert sectarianism.Cllr Lewis said while police may not be able to identy those responsible, he was told that neighbours can.ldquoThe aspiring republican artists should be thoroughly embarrassed by their actions and I only hope that their parents are reading this article, he declared.ldquoThis part of rural South Down suffered heavily as a direct result of IRA terrorism. Those with a spray can in one hand and a smartphone which accesses the internet in the other may have learnt or been fed a misguided, romanticised version of the troubles.ldquoI can assure them that their neighbours, the community which lives around them and which suffered day and daily do not need reminded of lsquoProvo brutalityrsquo nor do they expect to see such obvious triumphalism.Cllr Lewis believes that the paint daubed on the bridge is strikingly similar to that which was used to paint over a dual language sign at the Wateresk Road outside Dundrum.ldquoThis suggests to me that those involved may have been trying to create the illusion that the Irish language sign was attacked by unionist neighbours to create tension and sow ision, he declared. ldquoThis type of behaviour is not welcome, it is not wanted and needs to stop.Cllr Lewis said he was unable to remove the graffiti from the bridge and has asked the Department for Infrastructure to do it..prettyPhoto

title: Shoppers urged to shop local and spend £100 voucher in high street
story: PEOPLE across the district are being urged to spend their new pound High Street pre-paid voucher cards to support local businesses.The appeal by Newry, Mourne and Down Council comes after applications for the poundm scheme opened on Monday, with the first cards due to be issued later this week.The Northern Ireland Executiversquos programme mdash which applies to everyone over  mdash aims to help those businesses in retail and hospitality hit by the pandemic and comes after the local council recently launched a lsquomake it localrsquo initiative to support local traders.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason said this campaign not only shines a light on the key sectors represented across the district, but highlights how businesses have worked hard to establish a safe shopping practice in light of Covid- regulations.ldquoIt has been a particularly dficult period for our local traders and the voucher scheme is a great initiative that has come at an ideal time as we approach the winter holiday season, she said.ldquoThe initiative will help boost our local businesses following thein footfall and reduced trade brought about by the pandemic.Cllr Mason said the clear message is that Newry, Mourne and Down is open for business.She added: ldquoOur local businesses are outstanding, erse and resilient. Now is the time to step up and support them by making it local. I would strongly encourage people from within the district to avail of the voucher and shop locally.Downpatrick businessman Darren Kearney, who is the owner of Oakley Fayre, said the business is pleased to be open to near full capacity again, which has only been made possible with the support of staff and loyal customers.ldquoThis has been a dficult time for many industries and the hospitality industry has been hit very hard, so we welcome any incentive or investment scheme that will help bring people onto their local high street, he said.Mr Kearney added: ldquoSupporting local gives back to the small, family-run businesses that are the foundation of the Northern Ireland economy.Stormont Economy Minister Gordon Lyons is encouraging local businesses to support the initiative.He said the ldquounprecedented scheme, which closes on November , is designed to boost businesses across the retail, hospitality and service sectors following the impact of the Covid- pandemic.He is urging all businesses to show their support to help maximise the benefits of the Spend Local cards and to use them wisely, supporting the local economy and communities as a ldquolittle spend can have a big effect.Retail NI chief executive Glyn Roberts said the scheme comes on the back of a very challenging period for retailers right across Northern Ireland.ldquoThe High Street Support Scheme is a welcome step in the long road to recovery for Northern Irelandrsquos retailers and I would encourage everyone in our industry to think hard about how they can encourage people to use their pound spend local card with their business, he said.ldquoIt should be remembered that p in every pound spent in an independent retailer is recycled around the local economy. If consumers make a special effort to spend their pound with local traders, then they will also be ensuring the money also goes towards invigorating the wider community.Hospitality Ulster chief executive Colin Neill said the impact of Covid- continues to present major challenges for the hospitality industry across Northern Ireland.ldquoThere is a great deal of uncertainty in the industry at the minute, he said.ldquoThe pandemic has had a devastating impact right across the sector. We welcome the introduction of the High Street scheme, which is a great opportunity for people to support jobs of friends and family who work in hospitality while enjoying some of the best food and drink in the world.Meanwhile, both the business community and the public are warned to be on their guard against scammers attempting to take advantage of the scheme. The Department of the Economy said it will not be asking for personal bank details at any point during the scheme..prettyPhoto

title: Structures needed around Strangford ferry service
story: POLITICIANS from adjoining local authority areas met last week to continue their work in addressing issues in relation to the Strangford ferry service.Newry, Mourne and Down councillor Cadogan Enright met with his Ards and North Down counterpart, Joe Boyle.They have been working in tandem for some time to address issues around the ferry service with some success already under their belt, particularly on the Portaferry side of the waterway.Cllr Enright said a lot of the issues they have concerns about are under the control of the Department of Infrastructure, not the local ferry staff who, he said, ldquodo a great job.He explained that over the past year the councillors succeeded in securing a new early morning sailing from Portaferry for commuters and students alike.ldquoPrior to Covid, it was common for capacity issues in the morning, forcing some people to drive around the peninsula or leave their cars in Strangford, Cllr Enright explained.ldquoCllr Boyle and I are campaigning to reduce congestion in Strangford by having the ferry car park in the village used as part of the ferry operation as is currently the case Portaferry. This would help ensure that the centre of Strangford does not become a car park which happens regularly.Cllr Enright thanked residents for their support on the traffic issue in Strangford and confirmed that the Stormont department has accepted the traffic tailbacks causes problems and that the issue needs to be addressed.He said officials have allocated a small budget to employ additional staff to ensure that the dedicated ferry queuing area is utilised at peak periods to reduce congestion in the centre of the village.Cllr Boyle agrees that a permanent solution is required to address the queuing issue in Strangford.He continued: ldquoWe must promote tourism to its fullest potential on both sides of Strangford Lough. That means that we need structures in place that maintain a steady flow of traffic through both Strangford and Portaferry.ldquoWe simply cannot continue with Strangford village regularly coming to a standstill, with residents being seriously affected, creating a negative rather than positive impact on local businesses and le in general due to ferry traffic.Cllr Boyle said Strangford and Portaferry had much to gain from tourism, provided there were proper structures in place to deal with vehicles wishing to board vessels on either side of the lough.He said he has discussed the problem with Cllr Enright and they believe there is a simple, cost-effective solution to addressing the problem.Cllr Boyle said it is important that visitors and tourists have a positive, not negative experience of both villages, confirming that both politicians plan to progress the issue with senior Department for Infrastructure officials.He said they also hope to contact with Stormont Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon..prettyPhoto

title: Wheelchair beach access plan
story: THE possibility of trialling floating wheelchairs at beaches across the district is being considered by Newry, Mourne and Down Council.The move comes after the local authority was asked to address the lack of access to beaches for those with mobility problems and officers asked to look at potential solutions.A number of politicians say they recognise the need to do more to ensure beaches can be accessed by a wide range of people by providing floating wheelchairs and special matting to allow them to travel over sand to make it to the water.The issue was discussed at last weekrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee with officers agreeing to bring back a report for discussion next month.Initially, officials will examine access to Newcastle beach before focusing on others across the district.Local councillors Patrick Brown and Alan Lewis are spearheading the drive to provide improved beach access, especially as there a number of local facilities which have been awarded prestigious blue flag status which recognises their quality.In a report presented to members of the council committee last week, officers said they were currently investigating several options and a further report will be tabled in October.She also issued a reminder of ongoing consultation on so-called changing places provision which is designed to meet the needs of people with a range of mobility issues.Cllr Harte said not everyone in a wheelchair was mobile and would need a hoist. Therefore there wouldnrsquot be much point providing floating wheelchairsthe council did not have the facilities for these people to get into or access these wheelchairs.Independent councillor Jarlath Tinnelly said that the beach access issue had been raised with him throughout the summer and he called for other beaches to be included in the pilot.He said his only concern with the motion would be thata pilot project was being proposed, the councilrsquos blue flag beaches at Tyrella and Cranfield should be considered.ldquoThe experience of wheelchair users to get on to the beach and enjoy that same thrill is a priority and we should be doing whatever we can to facilitate that, he said.ldquoThese floating wheelchairs can be taken into the water and allow people to enjoy the same experiences as everybody , things that are taken for granted.The motion to improve beach access was initially tabled in August and was inspired by the campaigning work of local activist, Naomi Herron, who approached all her local councillors askingsomething could be done to give her better access to the beach.At the time, Cllr Brown said he understood that while a small scale trial of the idea has operated in Cranfield in the past, it was important that this was expanded out into other parts of the district and that he could ldquothink of no better place than Newcastle given the large number of visitors it gets every year.He continued: ldquoAs a council, it is important that we ensure all facilities are open and accessible to all residents. It is right that we look at the issue of beach access, with a view to providing provisions for wheelchair-bound residents and visitors who wish to also enjoy our wonderful coastline.ldquo I donrsquot want this issue to go around in circles with reports, meetings and investigations. It is my hope that from this motion we see action, movement toward making the necessary access points needed to facilitate this initiative. Disabled beach access is a reality in other towns within these islands why not Newcastle.Cllr Lewis said work was needed to ensure the entire district is disabled access friendly, from changing to toilet facilities.He added: ldquoIncreased footfall to Newcastle during the good weather has brought many of these issues to the fore. As councillors, we must challenge ourselves to ensure that our district is accessible and open to all by facilitating the extra provisions needed..prettyPhoto

story: Despite friendly talk from Mary Lou McDonald, republicans snub unionist requests such as marking the centenary of Northern Ireland   Dublin and Brussels ‘changing their tune’ on Northern Ireland Protocol: Sir Jeffrey DonaldsonNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionSpeaker of Lords: It’s been good toto see progress in Northern Ireland since my time as a government minister after the Belfast Agreement in sA letter from Lord McFall of Alcluith:By Lord McFallFriday, st October , : amUpdated Friday, st October , : am  "       "  The House of Lords Speaker, Lord McFall, right, with the Speaker of the Northern Ireland Assembly, Alex Maskey, at Stormonts Parliament Buildings on WednesdayWhen I was recently elected as Lord Speaker one of my priorities was to strengthen ties between the House of Lords and the devolved legislatures in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. That is why I am so pleased that this week my first official visit as Lord Speaker was to Belfast. I developed a great affection for the place when I served as a Northern Ireland Minister in the late s in the years after the Good Friday Agreement so it was brilliant to be back and see the progress that has been made. One of the important s of the Lord Speaker is to act as an ambassador for the House of Lords, explaining what we do and why, and building connections with the public. I am firmly of the view that Parliamentarians and Assembly Members can do a better job of holding our respective governments to accountwe work closely together on issues that affect us all. I very much enjoyed discussing that this week with Alex Maskey my counterpart in the Northern Ireland Assembly and other Assembly Members. Please try again later.Submitting...Letter to the editorI also met with community and volunteer groups doing fantastic work in Belfast. I heard lots of dferent views on the House of Lords but what is clear to me is that stereotypes about the House get in the way of the public understanding what we do and the role we play. The Lords has a key role in holding the Government to account both in improving legislation and through our Committees. In April the House appointed a dedicated Committee scrutinising the Protocol on Ireland Northern Ireland. That Committee has Members from Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK representing a range of views both on the Protocol and on Northern Ireland’s constitutional position. That Committee’s work will be influential in determining how policymakers respond to the current challenges. The Committee will be coming to Northern Ireland themselves in November to hear from businesses, community groups and politicians about their experience of the impact of the Protocol on the ground.The Lords plays a key role in improving legislation on behalf of the public. The wealth of expertise of Members of the Lords, including many from Northern Ireland, means real world knowledge is brought to bear in improving draft laws in a way that rarely happens in the Commons. To name just one example, the Environment Bill is about to be sent back to the Commons with at least  signicant amendments, ideas proposed by, among others, members of the Committee on Climate Change, leading engineers and distinguished environmental academics. These changes,agreed by the House of Commons will improve environmental protection and iron out defects that, without an expert second chamber, would have made it into law. I hope my trip this week will be just the start of engaging with the public and devolved legislatures right across the country. I want the House of Lords to be at the heart of the national conversation and it was pleasure to start that process in Belfast.Speaker of the House of Lords, Lord McFall of Alcluith——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: the dup has been a vital force within northern ireland unionism for five decades
story: Covid NI: What are the current Covid restrictions in Northern Ireland - from social distancing to international travel   Dublin and Brussels ‘changing their tune’ on Northern Ireland Protocol: Sir Jeffrey DonaldsonNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionThe DUP has been a vital force within Northern Ireland unionism for five decadesHappy birthday to the DUP, which reached it half century yesterday!By EditorialFriday, st October , : amUpdated Friday, st October , : am  "       "  News Letter editorialThe party has been a vital force within unionism for five decades.The late Reverend Dr Ian Paisley was an orator of international repute. His rise within the world of fundamentalist Christianity, at the start of the s, came almost two decades before his political success of . That year he became an MP at both Stormont and Westminster. The next year, Dr Paisley founded the Democratic Unionist Party.For three decades it never eclipsed the Ulster Unionist Party, except in limited instances such as the  council elections, and in all the elections to the European Parliament.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The latter successes were due to the huge personal vote for Rev Paisley and his firm line on terror, even from people who did not share his religion or approve of his detailed policies.For a while after the  Belfast Agreement, the DUP seemed marginalised on the Northern Ireland political scene, and adopted a strange position of working the new power sharing arrangements as ministers, while rejecting its ethos and refusing to attend executive meetings with Sinn Fein.Peter Robinson, whose bi weekly News Letter column is opposite, was almost as influential in the DUP as Dr Paisley. A close reading of his politics in the s suggests that he was on a long journey to accepting a new dispensation, which in  saw the party agree to share power with SF.For the better part of a decade, despite constant hiccups, the DUP seemed to be defying gravity in achieving stability with political irreconcilables, but now mandatory coalition seems to mired in problems as to be barely feasible any more.DUP pragmatism has often been appropriate and at times led to good government. After Brexit, and particularly after the  protocol, its pragmatism went too far. It also was too pragmatic on legacy, and went further even than some casual unionists could bear. It has toughened its stance on those issues, as was needed — it is a duty of the largest unionist party to set out clear boundaries beyond which it will never go.In the meantime, we wish the DUP well on its big anniversary and look back with gratitude at its vast achievements. ——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. Danni, , who ran a successful security firm prior to her accident, broke her back and now lives with a series of debilitating health problems.She says: "I didnrsquot realise that the hot weather had made the water level lower than normal. I was having the greatest time ndash Irsquod jumped nine times, until I made that one wrong move and now I have to live with the fact that I have fits, I have a stammer and I have endless hospital appointments."I went from being a   business owner and mother to being stuck in my bedroom, unable to move. It felt my le was just taken away and it was down to one mistake, one wrong move."If I had been better educated about the risks, I might have made a better choice about jumping that last time in the way I did."During the school holidays, Water Safety Wales, a group of more than  organisations focused on reducing drowning and serious incidents, are encouraging jumpers to stay safe.In the latest incident at the Blue Lagoon, near Abereiddy in Pembrokeshire, a person in their early s had to be airlted to hospital with back injuries. It follows an incident in April where a man suffered le changing injuries after jumping from clfs close to Langland Bay, Swansea, and another where a man was recovered unconscious from the water after jumping from clfs at St Catherinersquos Island, Tenby. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityGraham Loveluck-Edwards has announced the release of his new book Historic Pubs of Wales where he relishes in some of the more colourful myths, legends and stories from Wales ancient past and oldest pubs.Included in the book is The Captains We, in Sully,a house originally owned by a captain."I have always loved old pubs, and we are blessed to have so many belters here in Wales," added Mr Loveluck-Edwards.Graham Loveluck-Edwards out snapping some pubs for his book "For example, the pub which claims to have an elephant buried under its beer garden, or the pub where funeral parties take a short cut to the cemetery through the bar to keep an ancient right of access alive, or the pub that claims to have invented pancake day and so many more."In all, Ive compiled over  incredible stories based around  amazing old pubs - is there any truth to them "Some for sure, but this book captures them and puts them in the context of history so you can be the judge."MORE NEWS:The book also contains a travel guide so readers can go on a tour around Wales and visit all the pubs in the book.You can find out more at www.talesfromhistoricpubsofwales.The book is available to buy now "As you can imagine for such a book the research was relentless and thorough, and a lot of fun," he added."Pubs have had such a tough time in the last year with us going in and out of lockdowns and with the introduction of social distancing measures."Sixteenth centuryinns are usually a warren of tiny rooms so being two metres apart has made opening and trading near impossible for many."So, a book which celebrates all that is great about our old pubs, which tells people their history, where to find them and what to expect when you get there has been welcomed by all landlords." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - title: best autumn walks wales revealed   full list
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityGlobal travel site Big Travel  has released its list of the best walks in Wales.From epic coastal paths to easy family strolls to hard hilly hikes, the country has it all.Soyoursquore ready to embrace the great outdoors, these are Big Travel rsquos top walks to try.Chepstow to Tintern Abbey, Wye ValleyThe Wye Valley is an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty which stretches along the Welsh-English border.The five-mile walk from Chepstow to Tintern Abbey makes up part of the Wye Valley Walk.En route, you encounter enchanted forests paths, climb ancient stone steps and come across some wonderful viewpoints that make perfect picnic stops.Source of the Severn Trail, Hafren Forest, PowysThe seven-mile Source of the Severn Trail is a well-marked, well-trodden walk through the tranquil Hafren Forest.On this walk, yoursquoll be in the shade of majestic pine trees and yoursquoll pass waterfalls and moorland on your way to the trickling source of the River Severn.The spot is marked by a large wooden post.Llangollen Canal Path, LlangollenThis tranquil walk along the canal path takes you from Llangollen in North Wales to the Pontcysyllte Aqueduct, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.The Victorian engineer, Thomas Telford finished its construction in . It is made from local stone and is the tallest navigable aqueduct in the world.Wales Coast PathThis is the most epic walking route in Wales.The -mile Wales Coast Path runs from the Welsh border to Chepstow and traces the outline of the whole country.Along the way, yoursquoll encounter sweeping vistas, wonderful wildle and plenty of heritage sites. This walk showcases the best of the Welsh landscape.Pyg Track, SnowdoniaSnowdonia is a popular spot with walkers butyou are looking for one of the quieter trails to take, follow the Pyg track that starts in the Pen-y-Pass car park.     This scenic track is an easy walk with just a few steep bits.When you reach the top, yoursquoll be rewarded with sweeping views that take in Crib Goch and Llyn Llydaw Lake.Llanddwyn Island Circular Walk, AngleseyLlanddwyn Island is on the west coast of Anglesey. Here yoursquoll find the church of St Dwynwen, the Welsh patron saint of lovers.So, what better place for a romantic, hand-in-hand stroll with your loved one. The .-mile looped route begins in the Newborough Forest car park and takes you on a discovery of the island.You have to walk along Newborough beach to reach Llanddwyn, and this is one of the best beaches in North Wales, so be sure to pack your swimsuityou want to go for a dip.The Cambrian WayThe Cambrian Way is a long-distance route that takes you through the wilds of Wales.It stretches some  miles from Cardf to Conwy, but,you donrsquot have the time or energy to complete the whole route, just do the Cardf section.Following the nine-mile Cardf stretch, yoursquoll wander alongside canals, through pretty walks and into wonderful woodland and forests. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. Woodlands grant ndash to improve the bioersity and ecology of Victoria Square in Penarth.Friends of Victoria Square were granted pound, in  and conducted some baseline surveys on the Square including tree and ecology surveys, which enabled them to discuss potential improvements with ecologists, landscape architects, and the public at an open evening.In January of this year the National Heritage Lottery and Welsh Government Community Woodlands scheme granted funds to enable Friends of Victoria Square to continue with their project.Other recent work carried out by the group includes:Carrying out essential expert works to improve the health of trees on the SquarePlanting  new treesPreparing areas of wildflowers to hopefully bloom next yearCreating six log piles with planting surrounding themCreating a bog garden Providing access to water for wildleDeveloping a community garden with five raised bedsInstalling bird and bat boxesFriends of Victoria Square are now preparing to aerate the soil to help improve natural drainage in the area to prevent waterlogging in the winter which damages the perennial plants.Peter Blackburn, who is secretary of Friends of Victoria Square, said: ldquoWe looked at how we could improve the [waterlogging] situation without having to install drainage channels which would be disruptive and could damage tree roots.OTHER NEWS:ldquoThe system to be used by our contractors, Terrain Aeration, drills holes one metre deep at two metre centres, blasting air to create connecting fissures between the holes, enhancing natural drainage and improving the quality of the soil, also reducing compaction.Other plans for Victoria Square include:Planting bluebells and daffodils to bloom in spring Planting winter vegetables and flowers in the raised bedsCreating child-friendly mini ponds as a source of water for wildle Training staff to conduct nature trails in Installing wildle cameras next summer to enable wildle and ecology surveysCrowdfunding
